Award.AbstractNarration:
Political elites across the globe are considerably wealthier than the populations they represent. Many worry that wealthy citizens may be advantaged because election campaigns are expensive or because holding office requires giving up a job that only the wealthy may afford. There are also concerns that wealthy politicians may skew policies toward their economic interests—interests that may differ from much of the population. But how serious are these concerns? This project systematically collects data on the wealth of political elites in countries around the world to assess generally how (financially) representative politicians are of their citizens. The project analyzes such questions as the extent to which less expensive campaigns help the less wealthy candidates win, and how much the wealth of a country’s political elite influences its social and redistributive policies. The study’s results help us better understand the causes and consequences of economic inequality, policy-making and representation in different types of political systems.

Due to the lack of comparative data on politicians' wealth, there is virtually no existing larger-N cross-national work on how political institutions affect the disparity between the wealth of elected representatives and their constituents. This leaves our understanding of the causes and consequences of representational inequalities incomplete, as it is difficult to ascribe broad causes and extrapolate from existing single-country studies. This project collects data on politicians' wealth in fifty-one countries and creates comparable datasets of constituency and citizen wealth. Combining these data in novel ways with other cross-national datasets, the project examines through statistical analyses, natural experiments, and quantitative case studies a number of related research questions, such as the effect of campaign finance regulations and electoral rules on politician wealth, and the relationship between politicians' wealth and a country's social safety net policies. The resultant database helps facilitates research on political representation and policy-making, and may be used to inform policy decisions about the design, implementation, and uses of office-holders’ financial disclosures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project collected the first-ever dataset of wealth of politicians across the world, covering 41 countries and more than 24,000 national politicians. This dataset is used to describe the variation in how wealthy the political elites are relative to the populations they represent, and study the causes and consequences of such financial representation.

The data confirm the narrative commonly seen in the popular press that politicians are considerably wealthier than the populations they represent. However, there is also large variation across countries. In the US. the household of the average Member of Congress is about 20 times wealthier than the average household in the population. But the US is not an outlier in comparative perspective, occupying roughly the middle of the distribution. This politician-to-population wealth ratio in the US is dwarfed by ratios in countries like India, Thailand, or Ukraine, or South Africa, where the ratio exceeds 100 (that is, an average national politician is more than 100 times wealthier than the average household).

There is also large within-country variation in the wealth of politicians, with some countries exhibiting much greater inequality within the political elites than
other countries. In this respect, the US is an outlier, having a more unequal political elite than in most other countries for which the data was collected. This inequality is primarily driven by politicians who are very wealthy, being in the top 1% in terms of wealth in the entire population. 

Both within and across-country variation in wealth is strongly associated with
campaign finance regulations. Countries with campaign finance regimes that allow a greater role for private financing, through self-funding and private
contributions, and lower levels of public financing, tend to have wealthier elites, and particularly a larger share of the very wealthy politicians. Through case studies of campaign finance reforms in Chile and Brazil, the data suggest that less restrictive spending limits disproportionately advantage the wealthiest politicians, and primarily through the success of new, wealthy entrants.

The wealth of politicians is also strongly associated with societal wealth inequality. Societies with heavily skewed distributions of wealth and income tend to have wealthier as well as more unequal political elites. Campaign finance regulations also combine with wealth inequality in impacting the wealth of politicians: less restrictive rules are more strongly advantageous for the very wealthy when there is greater economic inequality.

Greater public financing helps to some extent redress the financial overpresentation of the wealthy in politics, but even if generous, it does not eliminate it. This is in part because public financing is often channelled to candidates through political parties. While parties tend to redistribute the funds to the less wealthy candidates to some degree, they cannot credibly commit to not financing the wealthier candidates as well, particularly where private donations and self-financing are also allowed. Such instruments help increase the probability of winning of wealthier candidates, and parties follow suit by supporting wealthier candidates to similar degree as the less wealthy candidates. This tendency is more pronounced when parties prioritize winning seats in the short term, such as when elections are especially close, or when there are unfavorable conditions like economic crises and instability.

In terms of consequences, wealthier politicians are ideologically more conservative, as revealed by the types of bills they sponsor or cosponsor, as well as the topic they focus on in parliamentary speeches. Wealthier politicians oversee less generous social and redistributive policies, as well as lower taxes on inome, capital gains and wealth. They also preside over more uneqal economic outcomes.

Wealthier politicians are more likely to be members of powerful parliamentary
committees, particuarly those involved in economic policymaking. The executive branch tends to have wealthier individuals than legislatures. Wealthier politicians also exert influence in their parties by helping finance their co-partisan colleagues' campaigns and financially supporting their parties' operations. These instruments help wealthier politicians wield greater influence than the less wealthy politicians in politics and policymaking.
